title: AT&T Earnings Top Views, Sales Light; CEO, Chairman Roles To Be Split
text:
AT&T earnings edged by third-quarter analyst estimates while revenue fell short of Wall Street targets, the company said Monday. But AT&T stock climbed as the company unveiled a plan that includes splitting the chairman and chief executive roles.

X

AT&T (T) said Monday that Chairman and CEO Randall Stephenson would stay on through at least 2020, but it agreed to separate the two roles when he leaves. The plan is part of a three-year outlook and capital allocation blueprint in response to pressure from activist investor Elliott Management. In September, Elliott Management disclosed a $3.2 billion stake in AT&T.

Meanwhile, the telecom and media conglomerate's earnings rose 4% vs. a year earlier to an adjusted 94 cents a share, topping views by a penny. AT&T revenue fell 2.5% to $44.6 billion.

A year earlier, AT&T earned 90 cents a share on sales of $45.74 billion. Analysts expected AT&T earnings of 93 cents a share on revenue of $45 billion for the period ended Sept. 30.

AT&T added 101,000 postpaid wireless phone customers, topping estimates of 61,000.

AT&T Stock: Entertainment Unit Still Struggles

The company's entertainment unit continues to struggle. AT&T said it lost 1.2 million pay-TV customers while also shedding 195,000 subscribers to the DirecTVNow internet TV service. The company has stopped promotions aimed at low-profit customers.

AT&T stock edged up 1.3% to 37.40 in premarket trading on the stock market today. Shares in AT&T have gained nearly 30% in 2019, despite the escalating video subscriber losses

On Tuesday AT&T is expected to update investors on its new subscription video streaming services anchored by HBO. At the analyst day, AT&T could announce a stock buyback to ease worries over earnings dilution from the cost of launching video streaming services. AT&T plans to launch the service in the spring of 2020.

AT&T said it will target revenue growth of 1% to 2% over the next three years and will pay off debt related to the Time Warner acquisition in 2018.

AT&T management has signaled that it won't sell satellite TV broadcaster DirecTV, acquired in 2015
